"Some bacteria cultured in a laboratory have gained the ability to use citrate as an energy source. We have had lots of queries about this matter, so this is our weekend feedback to all those who have asked.

A New Scientist article proclaims:

‘Lenski’s experiment is also yet another poke in the eye for anti-evolutionists, notes Jerry Coyne, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Chicago. “The thing I like most is it says you can get these complex traits evolving by a combination of unlikely events,” he says. “That’s just what creationists say can’t happen.”’1

The many comments posted on the New Scientist website shows just how excited the atheists are about this report. They are positively gloating.

The context
In 1988, Richard Lenski, Michigan State University, East Lansing, founded 12 cultures of E. coli and grew them in a laboratory, generation after generation, for twenty years (he deserves some marks for persistence!). The culture medium had a little glucose but lots more citrate, so once the microbes consumed the glucose, they would continue to grow only if they could evolve some way of using citrate. Lenski expected to see evolution in action. This was an appropriate expectation for one who believes in evolution, because bacteria reproduce quickly and can have huge populations, as in this case. They can also sustain higher mutation rates than organisms with much larger genomes, like vertebrates such as us.2 All of this adds up, according to neo-Darwinism, to the almost certainty of seeing lots of evolution happen in real time (instead of imagining it all happening in the unobservable past). With the short generation times, in 20 years this has amounted to some 44,000 generations, equivalent to some million years of generations of a human population (but the evolutionary opportunities for humans would be far, far less, due to the small population numbers limiting the number of mutational possibilities; and the much larger genome, which cannot sustain a similar mutation rate without error catastrophe; i.e. extinction; and sexual reproduction means that there is 50% chance of failing to pass on a beneficial mutation ).

As noted elsewhere (see ‘Giving up on reality’), Lenski seemed to have given up on ‘evolution in the lab’ and resorted to computer modelling of ‘evolution’ with a program called Avida (see evaluation by Dr Royal Truman, Part 1 and Part 2, which are technical papers). Indeed, Lenski had good reason to abandon hope. He had calculated1 that all possible simple mutations must have occurred several times over but without any addition of even a simple adaptive trait.

Lenski and co-workers now claim that they have finally observed his hoped for evolution in the lab.

The science: what did they find?
In a paper published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science, Lenski and co-workers describe how one of 12 culture lines of their bacteria has developed the capacity for metabolizing citrate as an energy source under aerobic conditions.3

This happened by the 31,500th generation. Using frozen samples of bacteria from previous generations they showed that something happened at about the 20,000th generation that paved the way for only this culture line to be able to change to citrate metabolism. They surmised, quite reasonably, that this could have been a mutation that paved the way for a further mutation that enabled citrate utilization.

This is close to what Michael Behe calls ‘The Edge of Evolution’—the limit of what ‘evolution’ (non-intelligent natural processes) can do. For example, an adaptive change needing one mutation might occur every so often just by chance. This is why the malaria parasite can adapt to most antimalarial drugs; but chloroquine resistance took much longer to develop because two specific mutations needed to occur together in the one gene. Even this tiny change is beyond the reach of organisms like humans with much longer generation times.4 With bacteria, there might be a chance for even three coordinated mutations, but it’s doubtful that Lenski’s E. coli have achieved any more than two mutations, so have not even reached Behe’s edge, let alone progressed on the path to elephants or crocodiles.

Now the popularist treatments of this research (e.g. in New Scientist) give the impression that the E. coli developed the ability to metabolize citrate, whereas it supposedly could not do so before. However, this is clearly not the case, because the citric acid, tricarboxcylic acid (TCA), or Krebs, cycle (all names for the same thing) generates and utilizes citrate in its normal oxidative metabolism of glucose and other carbohydrates.5

Furthermore, E. coli is normally capable of utilizing citrate as an energy source under anaerobic conditions, with a whole suite of genes involved in its fermentation. This includes a citrate transporter gene that codes for a transporter protein embedded in the cell wall that takes citrate into the cell.6 This suite of genes (operon) is normally only activated under anaerobic conditions.

So what happened? It is not yet clear from the published information, but a likely scenario is that mutations jammed the regulation of this operon so that the bacteria produce citrate transporter regardless of the oxidative state of the bacterium’s environment (that is, it is permanently switched on). This can be likened to having a light that switches on when the sun goes down—a sensor detects the lack of light and turns the light on. A fault in the sensor could result in the light being on all the time. That is the sort of change we are talking about.

it has no relevance to the origin of enzymes and catalytic pathways that evolution is supposed to explain
Another possibility is that an existing transporter gene, such as the one that normally takes up tartrate,3 which does not normally transport citrate, mutated such that it lost specificity and could then transport citrate into the cell. Such a loss of specificity is also an expected outcome of random mutations. A loss of specificity equals a loss of information, but evolution is supposed to account for the creation of new information; information that specifies the enzymes and cofactors in new biochemical pathways, how to make feathers and bone, nerves, or the components and assembly of complex motors such as ATP synthase, for example.

However, mutations are good at destroying things, not creating them. Sometimes destroying things can be helpful (adaptive),7 but that does not account for the creation of the staggering amount of information in the DNA of all living things. Behe (in The Edge of Evolution) likened the role of mutations in antibiotic resistance and pathogen resistance, for example, to trench warfare, whereby mutations destroy some of the functionality of the target or host to overcome susceptibility. It’s like putting chewing gum in a mechanical watch; it’s not the way the watch could have been created.

Much ado about nothing (again)
Behe is quite right; there is nothing here that is beyond ‘the edge of evolution’, which means it has no relevance to the origin of enzymes and catalytic pathways that evolution is supposed to explain.8

"Evolution" mixes two things together, one real, one imaginary.  People are shown the real part, which makes them ready to believe the imaginary part.  That is how the idea of biological evolution has spread since 1859.  Variation is the real part. There are strict limits to variation that are never crossed, something every breeder of animals or plants is aware of.  Whenever variation is pushed to extremes by selective breeding (to get the most milk from cows, sugar from beets, bristles on fruit flies, or any other characteristic), the line becomes sterile and dies out.  And as one characteristic increases, others diminish.  But evolutionists want you to believe that changes continue, merging gradually into new kinds of creatures.  This is where the imaginary part of the theory of evolution comes in.  It says that new information is added to the gene pool by mutation and natural selection to create frogs from fish, reptiles from frogs, and mammals from reptiles, to name a few.
Just to be clear, evolution theory puts no limit on what mutation/natural selection can invent, saying that everything in nature was invented by it - everything:
sex, eye-hand coordination, balance, navigation systems, tongues, blood, antennae, waste removal systems, swallowing, joints, lubrication, pumps, valves, autofocus, image stabilization, sensors, camouflage, traps, ceramic teeth, light (bioluminescence), ears, tears, eyes, hands, fingernails, cartilage, bones, spinal columns, spinal cords, muscles, ligaments, tendons, livers, kidneys, thyroid glands, lungs, stomachs, vocal cords, saliva, skin, fat, lymph, body plans, growth from egg to adult, nurturing babies, aging, breathing, heartbeat, hair, hibernation, bee dancing, insect queens, spiderwebs, feathers, seashells, scales, fins, tails, legs, feet, claws, wings, beaver dams, termite mounds, bird nests, coloration, markings, decision making, speech center of the brain, visual center of the brain, hearing center of the brain, language comprehension center of the brain, sensory center of the brain, memory, creative center of the brain, object-naming center of the brain, emotional center of the brain, movement centers of the brain, center of the brain for smelling, immune systems, circulatory systems, digestive systems, endocrine systems, regulatory systems, genes, gene regulatory networks, proteins, ribosomes that assemble proteins, receptors for proteins on cells, apoptosis, hormones, neurotransmitters, circadian clocks, jet propulsion, etc.  Everything in nature - according to evolution theory.  
Here is how the imaginary part is supposed to happen: On rare occasions a mutation in DNA improves a creature's ability to survive, so it is more likely to reproduce (natural selection).  That is evolution's only tool for making new creatures.  It might even work if it took just one gene to make and control one part.  But parts of living creatures are constructed of intricate components with connections that all need to be in place for the thing to work, controlled by many genes that have to act in the proper sequence.  Natural selection would not choose parts that did not have all their components existing, in place, connected, and regulated because the parts would not work.  Thus all the right mutations (and none of the destructive ones) must happen at the same time by pure chance.  That is physically impossible.  To illustrate just how hopeless it is, imagine this: on the ground are all the materials needed to build a house (nails, boards, shingles, windows, etc.).  We tie a hammer to the wagging tail of a dog and let him wander about the work site for as long as you please, even millions of years.  The swinging hammer on the dog is as likely to build a house as mutation-natural selection is to make a single new working part in an animal, let alone a new creature.
Only mutations in the reproductive (germ) cells of an animal or plant would be passed on.  Mutations in the eye or skin of an animal would not matter.  Mutations in DNA happen fairly often, but most are repaired or destroyed by mechanisms in animals and plants.  All known mutations in animal and plant germ cells are neutral, harmful, or fatal.  But evolutionists are eternally optimistic.  They believe that millions of beneficial mutations built every type of creature that ever existed.

Believing in beneficial mutations is like believing a short-circuit in the motherboard of your computer could improve its performance.  To make any lasting change, a beneficial mutation would have to spread ("sweep") through a population and stay (become "fixed").  To evolutionists, this idea has been essential for so long that it is called a "classic sweep", "in which a new, strongly beneficial mutation increases in frequency to fixation in the population."

Some evolutionist researchers went looking for classic sweeps in humans, and reported their findings in the journal Science.  "To evaluate the importance of classic sweeps in shaping human diversity, we analyzed resequencing data for 179 human genomes from four populations".  "In humans, the effects of sweeps are expected to persist for approximately 10,000 generations or about 250,000 years."  Evolutionists had identified "more than 2000 genes as potential targets of positive selection in the human genome", and they expected that "diversity patterns in about 10% of the human genome have been affected by linkage to recent sweeps."  So what did they find?  "In contrast to expectation," their test detected nothing, but they could not quite bring themselves to say it.  They said there was a "paucity of classic sweeps revealed by our findings".  Sweeps "were too infrequent within the past 250,000 years to have had discernible effects on genomic diversity."  "Classic sweeps were not a dominant mode of human adaptation over the past 250,000 years." --Hernandez, Ryan D., Joanna L. A 35-year experiment by evolutionists shows how things really work.  Instead of waiting for natural selection, researchers forced selection on hundreds of generations of fruit flies.  They used variation to breed fruit flies that develop from egg to adult 20% faster than normal.  But, as usual when breeding plants and animals, there was a down side.  In this case the fruit flies weighed less, lived shorter lives, and were less resistant to starvation.  There were many mutations, but none caught on, and the experiment ran into the limits of variation.  They wrote that "forward experimental evolution can often be completely reversed with these populations".  "Despite decades of sustained selection in relatively small, sexually reproducing laboratory populations, selection did not lead to the fixation of newly arising unconditionally advantageous alleles."  "The probability of fixation in wild populations should be even lower than its likelihood in these experiments." --Burke, Molly K., Joseph P. Interesting, but the problem of Darwins original Theory of Evolution, is that it has had to be divided into Micro Evolution & Macro Evolution.
Micro Evolution exampled: means a Finch (small bird with strong beak) can develop a larger even stronger beak in response to a shortage of food supply, so that the bigger beak can allow the bird to feed on more diverse foodstuffs.
Macro Evolution: A major change such as Fish growing legs and lungs to enable them to leave the Ocean and become a land animal. This is now thought to be impossible. For the simple reason that the necessary change requires a number of new body parts, each of which forms only a tiny part of the whole required change. In other words you can't just develop legs because the legs themselves need dozens of new bits to make the leg, such as bones, muscles etc, and each part needs to be developed one part at a time.

If one part at a time was evolved, in preparation for a secondary and then further subsequent parts. The first part evolved being useless would be lost in a subsequent generation, before it could be built upon. This is because the mechanism for evolution cannot in reality "see" or "foresee" the environmental changes around it. As a result the creature involved dies out instead.

This is probably not an improvement, it is only an action of increasing the activity of only one vital metabolic function (growth by using glucose) at the expense of others (adaptation to temperature, nutritional shortage, competition, etc.).

It is unbelievable how many misunderstandings are there about Darwin's evolution. Unfortunately many of them can be found in this video. First, Lenski's experiment is not about Darwin's evolution whose book was titled "On the Origin of Species".  E.coli is not a species and, respectively, there is no way that an adaptation process can result in the origin of a new E.coli species. Second, Darwin is not an author of concepts of adaptation or natural selection. They were proposed long before him. In fact, Lenski's experiment is about adaptation and origin of new variants of a bacteria proliferating by mitosis (in contrast to meiosis required for Darwinian evolution). As an example of evolution, Darwin talks about evolution from bears to whales (because bears swim for hours). In contrast adaptation talks about an ability to survive in the presence of a toxin, for example again. The analogous for this would be development of tolerance to a mosquito or snake bite in humans. At some point though you still hit a limit and the bacteria will create so much heat that they kill themselves.

The other problem is oxygen. If you keep increasing the size of the system it becomes harder and harder to get enough oxygen into the solution. What you end up with is large areas with no oxygen as it has all been consumed before it gets to those area. Adding oxygen is really hard to do at larger sizes because diffusion is not enough but you also can't create bubbles. The gas/liquid interface created by a bubble has a large shearing force which is destructive to a lot of single cell organisms.

About the dish cloth: It should be noted that, while a damp environment like it is an excellent place for bacteria to breed, and it can definitely spread them, this is a problem that pretty much takes care of itself.
Soap, be it dish soap or hand soap, is quite good at killing bacteria. As the two sides of a soap molecule are rather aggressively lipophilic and hydrophilic respectively, they attract the molecules in the bacteria's cell membranes, importantly also their lipohilic sides "hidden" at the center of the membrane, with enough force to destroy the cells. This is why washing your hands is so effective at preventing the spread of Covid 19, because even regular hand soap literally destroys the virus. (This is also why you shouldn't eat tide pods.)
Of course, a dish cloth will also often be used without soap, for example to clean up spills. In these cases, you are spreading bacteria. However, whenever you apply soap to the cloth, you are effectively disinfecting it.
And while paper towels can thus prevent the spread of bacteria and are often rather convenient, they also do create potentially avoidable waste.

I realize that this is a sponsorship and that sponsorships are important, and obviously nothing wrong is being said in that context in this video, but I did want to point out to anyone who might care that there is no reason to replace all your cleaning cloths with paper towels.

You can also argue that there must be an asymptote from game theory. If you believe every game, no matter how complex, has an optimal strategy then it follows that there must also be an asymptote.

The fact that a power law fits the data better than an asymptotic curve is compelling, but an asymptotic curve can also fit the data if you extend the time axis to very large values such that it "hides" its asymptotic nature. That together with the points stated above lead me to believe there has to be an asymptote for fitness growth.

this is highly misleading and Lenski knows better - normal E. coli has a citric acid cycle / citrate metabolism mechanism already built in. It is normally suppressed at the genetic level in aerobic conditions (ie, conditions of this expt.). But breaking the suppressor protein mechanism allows the E. coli to swap citrate for succinate and thus metabolise the citrate. (The succinate is taken back up again to repeat the cycle.) So, nothing new 'evolved' here, an existing mechanism at the cell membrane level was broken to switch on a standard E. coli process. Bacteria have a range of these mechanisms for alternate food sources which are normally kept off as it would be wasteful to turn them on before required. This aspect of the expt. explained much better (more honestly) by Van Hofwegen, Minnich, and Hovde (2016), J. of Bacteriology.

These E. coli have always had the ability to process citrate but the DNA code to produce the enzymes to process citrate is normally blocked because in their natural environment, producing those enzymes would be a waste of energy and resources for the bacteria. In their special environment, it was advantageous to be able to process citrate. When some bacterium in this special solution failed to produce the protein that down-regulated the DNA from producing citrate processing enzymes – most likely because of a broken genetic code for the regulating protein – then the citrate processing enzymes began being produced and that particular bacterium had an advantage.

In other words, the advantage was gained because of a broken gene that regulated an already existing gene. There was no new DNA code. There was no new capability that didn't exist before. The E. coli already have programmed into their DNA codes for adaptation to different environments. This is not Darwinian evolution. This is adaptation using capabilities that already existed in E. coli. The E. coli processing the citrate have lost diversity because they can no longer regulate citrate processing enzymes. In a natural environment, these E. coli would have a distinct disadvantage over natural E. coli and would die out.

I think a lot of people are having a few issues understanding some key points. Maybe this will help clarify.

1. OH NO! Super bacteria! Dangerous!
There is nothing super or dangerous about this bacteria. It's non-pathogenic (meaning it doesn't infect you) E. coli, which is already present inside you by the billion. And the E. coli in your guts are playing out a game of survival with other bacteria, your body, and bacteriophages; these pressures encourage the evolution of traits that could be dangerous. The bacteria in this experiment just got better at glucose and citrate metabolism. There is no concern of anything dangerous coming out of this. You could drink one of those flasks and the absolute worst thing to occur would be food poisoning.

2. This isn't evolution, it's adaptation.
Evolution is just a change in allele frequency in a population over time. Which is obviously what occurred here. Additionally, adaptation requires evolution. So saying it's just adaptation doesn't make sense, adaptation is evolution. If you wanted a giraffe to crawl out of the flask in order for it to be evolution, I think you need to review some ecology and genetics texts. Evolution doesn't require speciation, and you wouldn't expect it here. This is a very stable environment, which conventionally wouldn't be considered a situation where evolution occurs at all. That was the point of this experiment, to show evolution occurs even in environmental stasis. And amazingly, it did. That is why this experiment is so awesome.

3. It's still bacteria!
This is exactly what the modern synthesis would predict. You don't ever stop being something, as monophyly would demonstrate. You don't outrun your ancestry. A bacteria will never stop being bacteria, the same way you will never stop being a eukaryote. If this is confusing, a review of cladistics will help piece that together.

E. coli is normally capable of utilizing citrate as an energy source under anaerobic conditions. What's noteworthy here is the mutated bacteria can now metabolize citrate under aerobic conditions. They found two mutations that did not break the controls of the citrate transporter gene, but but bypassed the controls altogether by duplicating the transporter gene to a location independent of the controls so the duplicate transporter gene is always on, even in aerobic conditions. A mere duplication or stuttering error is not exactly new information, and you need new information to make robust changes in organisms.
The use of an amplification process to make aerobic utilization of citrate more efficient and all the other human interventions negates natural selection somewhat, increasing the tens of thousands of generations that were reported by many times. So called evolution is a very bumpy ride and the time factor is not always your friend.
The mutated E. coli have about a 20% reduced ability to feed on glucose, and have lost the ability to turn off the production of the citrate transporter gene and are wasting resources producing this unneeded citrate transporter. These mutated bacteria would not be able to compete in a natural environment.

For some reason, this kind of reminds me of Trading Card Games like Yugioh and Magic the Gathering. In both games, the avatars have offense and defense stats which are fairly involved in turn-to-turn interactions, but if you try to build a deck around just having really high offense and defense stats, while that might have been a viable strategy once upon a time the games have Power Crept so much since then that such a deck would practically be unusable.

To those unfamiliar with the term, Power Creep is basically, as Extra Credits put it "the concept that over time, elements introduced to a game grow in power", in other words "the process by which older stuff becomes obsolete by newer stuff constantly raising the bar for entry". Maybe you summon avatars more easily, maybe avatars are harder to kill, maybe avatars are better at getting rid of other avatars by means other than high offense value, maybe avatars have less of a maintenance cost, etc.

Point is, the evolution of Trading Card Games and even some video games aren't that unlike real life evolution of organisms. The way I've heard my dad talk about programing/coding reminds me of deck building too, the way each individual component of the deck informs the strategy/objective of the deck, and how that same (or at least very similar) objective can be fulfilled by other cards, and how many of those same cards can be used in other decks with completely different objectives, and how otherwise useless components can be rendered extremely helpful in the right context and vice versa.
No matter how good a deck is, it's not unbeatable and that the bigger the deck is (in games where the deck size is variable), the harder it is to avoid dead draws (which is when you draw cards from your deck completely unhelpful to resolving your current situation. Basically the smaller your deck is- the more likely you are to get the card you need when you need it, not unlike how the more complex the program- the more likely you are to get glitches/bugs).

However I object to the term “Evolution in Action!” Here’s why:

Dr Lenski spoke about one line of E. Coli starting to metabolise citrate. However, he failed to mention that E. coli DOES use citrate but its citric acid cycle switches off in the presence of oxygen. The bacteria normally live in hypoxic or anoxic conditions (little or no oxygen), where they ARE able to use citrate.

Imagine you had those solar lights for the garden that automatically come on when light conditions are low. If one of them began to stay on all the time, even in bright sunshine you would assume a fault in the light sensing/on/off mechanism. It would be ridiculous to say it had “Evolved” the ability to do this!

But it seems almost as ridiculous (except of course that solar lights don’t breed!) to say that the mutated E. Coli “Evolved” because of mutations affecting its citrate processing’s “Off switch” (or whatever the mechanism causing the change) or its ability to resist antibiotics.



So I have a few questions:

• What are the genetic mechanisms that produce antibiotic resistance in the experiment mentioned? For example, a mutation in the mechanism that takes substances into the cell might prevent the poison being absorbed.



• Do any of the E.coli cells show signs of developing completely new genetic information that would change them into different kind of bacteria, or anything else?

• What is your definition of evolution?

The experiment has so far failed to show any genetic change that could eventually turn E. Coli into an amoeba – or into anything except more E. Coli. Believing that it would undergo any such change if continued long enough is an example of wishful thinking or even “Blind faith”. (Unless you cheat and decided to name a particular strain a new species!)

The academics referenced below are mainstream secular biologists and philosophers of Science. None of them believes in creationism, intelligent design or anything like that. It is important to highlight this as the impression that many people have is that only religious people criticize evolutionary theory. 

Evolution and Darwinism:
First thing we need to do is to make a distinction between evolution and Darwin’s theory of evolution also known as Darwinism or Neo Darwinism. On a public level these terms are thought to be the same, however academically they are not. So what is the difference? Evolution as a general concept means ‘biological change over time’. On the other hand Darwinian evolution has two parts, the history of life being represented by a tree, where all the organisms that have ever lived go back to one common origin and secondly that natural selection is the primary driving mechanism behind all this biological change.  
Evolution is a basic observation in nature, we can see it before our very eyes. This basic type of evolution is simply true, it is happening all around us, butterfly populations change biologically over time, bacteria evolve resistance to medicine, fish lose traits that are detrimental over time etc. No one disagrees with this type of biological evolution being ubiquitous and this was well known before Darwin. Even the most primitive human being who has had no interaction with the civilized world would agree that this evolution is an undeniable observation. Darwinian Evolution is way more than this basic observable evolution it claims that all of life evolved from a single cell and all the biological change happened primarily due to natural selection.   
Although it is absolutely clear that there is a difference between evolution and Darwinism, the public thinks they are one and the same. This confusion is not inconsequential. This is because people conflate this apparent observable evolution with Darwinian Evolution. They think evidence for the former is evidence for the latter and this is simply not true. Darwinian evolution has the twin thesis of the tree of life and natural selection and these require evidence other than the basic observation of evolution itself. Clarifying this distinction is important. So one who claims they are the same and uses this to argue for the truth of Darwinian evolution is actually committing a fallacy of equivocation.  
Darwinian evolution is based on a probabilistic framework which has assumptions and importantly there are ongoing disputes and doubts about its central claims.

2:40 "It means if we see the same thing happening in replicate populations, it's not because they started out with the same genetic variants and natural selection just fished out the same thing over and over."

No, that's exactly what it means. There's a certain amount of genetic variation in all species, and environmental conditions can cause certain traits more or less effective for the survival of the species, so those traits become more prominent, as less desirable genetics are bred out of the population.

This is seen in many varieties of fish. In the absense of predators, the brightest color males will have more oportunities to procreate, and they'll become more prominent than dull-colored males. But if there are large numbers of predators, many of the bright colored males will get picked off, and consequently the dull-colored males will have more oportunities to reproduce, and the population demographic will change to be dominated by dull-colored males. This isn't evolution, it's the variation already built into the species.

You could keep doing your gain-of-function research on E-coli forever, but it will never turn into anything other than a bacteria. It will never "evolve" into something more. You can use the environment to select for certain traits, but it will never develop traits it wasn't genetically able to manifest from the beginning.

Veritasium, I think Richard Lenski has taken you for a ride here and considerably oversold the results of his research. I remember the hype surrounding the citrate result, with headlines like 'Lenski's bacteria learn to eat citrate! Evolution in action!' But the reality is much more modest. All the biochemical pathways for metabolising citrate (Krebs cycle) were present in the original E. coli population. But the bacteria preferentially fed on glucose because a genetic switch ensured that citrate metabolism was switched off in the presence of oxygen. What happened during Lenski's experiment was elucidated by Zachary Blount and reported in Nature in 2012. A mutation damaged the switch, turning citrate metabolism on even when oxygen was present. This was followed by a double duplication of an existing gene which enhanced the effect. Note no new genetic information was created. This was confirmed by Van Hofwegen et al in a report published in the Journal of Bacteriology in 2016. This report stated: 'We conclude that the rarity of the LTEE [Lenski’s long-term evolution experiment] mutant was an artifact of the experimental conditions and not a unique evolutionary event. No new genetic information (novel gene function) evolved.' Michael Behe has followed Lenski's experiment closely and given a fair assessment of it in his two most recent books, Darwin Devolves and A Mousetrap for Darwin. He is appreciative of the effort Lenski and his coworkers have put in, but concludes that the results only show the limits of Darwinian mechanisms, with apparent increases in fitness being overwhelmingly attributable to genes being broken.

Optimizing this network was quite difficult, so I built an algorithm that built random orbit networks. Then it mutated them, building different mutations and kept the best. This went over and over. BUT: I wanted to create a perfect result with 100% effiency. I was sure there was one. I let the algorithm keep on mutating two more nights. There were still mutations, but not so much anymore. The result stabilized. It got trapped in something like a false evolution state. I was sure there would be a better state. But the current "stable" quickly elimanted other solutions, that WOULD evolve into something better. It's difficult to explay. It's like having the first car-machine, and because the first car-machines are worse than good horses they are quickly eliminated and the horses win.
I tried several things to get this selection out of this conservative state, but nothing really helped. I then bred new generations from scratch at some point. Over and over again. This is so far from actual evolution in action as the east is from the west. It is thoroughly looked at in this article from 2008 already, (search for "Bacteria evolving in the lab? by Don Batten"), and in summary, it’s a lot of hot air, and actually proves how totally bankrupt evolution is, grasping at straws. What happened to the bacteria was in short:
E. coli is normally capable of utilizing citrate as an energy source under anaerobic conditions. But in the mutated bacterium, the transporter gene was duplicated (copied) to a different location away from the existing control sequence such that the production of the transporter is no longer suppressed in the presence of oxygen.
So the ability of the cell to control the production of the citrate transporter was indeed broken (the cell is no longer able to turn off the production of the transporter)
The sorts of ‘evolutionary’ (read ‘natural’) innovations observed give no support to the idea that microbes changed into microbiologists. This would require not just duplication of existing genes, breaking of control systems, or co-opting of existing control systems, but the origin of thousands of brand new gene families (each gene family is so-called because they are quite different to other gene families) that are missing from microbes, along with their control systems.
There have been so many generations of E. coli cultured that every possible point mutation has occurred in the E. coli genome, and yet this is the best they can come up with! This is hardly an example of a great evolutionary leap forward! In reality it underlines the limitations of mutations to create the new gene families needed for evolution to be a viable scientific model of the origin of the diversity of life.

Rather evidence points to the ability of organisms to alter inheritable traits in response to environmental changes. That is, organisms alter their offspring in a non random fashion. The emerging understanding of the non random source of genetic diversity and hence evolution is discussed by a leader in the field, James Shapiro a cell biologist from Univ of Chicago. You made a claim in this video that I think is incorrect, at least as my understanding goes. You said that having a mutation rate which is too high is bad because it leads to offspring with too many deleterious mutations. As I understand it, this is not the problem at all. You would have to get to a very, very extreme mutation rate for that to be the case, and prior lineages would just die out before they could even get that far due to the actual problem with a high mutation rate - discarding beneficial mutations. If an organism with a beneficial mutation occurs, a high mutation rate means the benefit will most likely be mutated out of the genome faster than the benefit can be felt. It's similar to the reason that organisms with shorter lifespans tend to win in competitions like these where the only differentiator is lifespan at the beginning. The long-living organisms can't acquire and hold on to beneficial mutations faster than the short-lived ones can evolve away from bad mutations.

Evolution never stops because of waste. Think about it, if you had a theoretically perfect organism, likely a bacteria or something simple like that because they are the most adaptable, covering the entire surface of the planet, what then? It dies in waste. All living systems, at the widest possible definition, are localized reduction of entropy which requires increasing entropy and, crucially, requires increasing the entropy *in their local environment*. They leave waste. That, alone, creates an evolutionary niche. Something which evolves to consume that waste will outcompete the organisms which can only produce it. But, that organism will also have to produce waste. The second law of thermodynamics becomes an engine of evolution, making any 'optimal' situation nonsensical. There is only evolving better ways to deal with the waste of other systems which are themselves evolving. This sort of thing can even be seen in abstract cellular automata or genetic algorithms, the waste can be some miniscule change in a shared state, but that's all it takes. That little kick of entropy from a "living" (the word 'living' actually has no definable meaning, but that's a different topic) system which just wants to reduce entropy in its own little pocket of the universe gives rise to evolution.

In evolution, mutations are constantly happening and some of those make no difference to the ability to survive, but some do, and that lineage survives and carries on that trait and it becomes more and more present in the population. But by randomly taking 1% of the population and destroying the rest, you're not really getting the real picture, because the chance that a small portion of the population with a favorable mutation survives is not influenced so much by it's ability to survive better, but rather by the chance that it's in the right place at the right time. To me, it seems that, you're seeing changes and mutations, but not necessarily the ones that were suited to survive better, but rather, ones that were selected by chance.

Darwinian Evolution implies the addition of information (genetic code) not it’s loss.
Both mutations attributed to the Linski’s findings represent a loss of information. In one case citric acid metabolism has become uncoupled to oxidative stress. All E. coli can metabolize citrate. In fact citrate formation and metabolism is an intermediate step in the Kreb’s cycle in glucose metabolism. This mutation produces excess enzymes to metabolize citrate even when citrate is absent which is an inefficient use of cellular resources.
Allegorical example: having your car engine running to transport you is good when needed but being unable to turn it off when parked is not so good.
The other mutation involves the loss of specificity for a tartrate transport protein that will also transport citrate into the cell. This is a loss of specificity and raises the oxidative stress in the cell.
Both mutations are a loss of regulation, a los of information, are deleterious and reduce reproductive viability and actually represent “de-evolution.”

Not only can some bacteria inherit their resistance to antibiotics from previous immune generations; they can also have resistance genes from other bacteria transferred to them.
Genes are transmitted between bacteria by means of plasmids, tiny DNA circles in bacteria in which resistance genes are often found encoded. These genes allow the bacteria to become resistant to various toxic materials in their surroundings.
Resistance genes may also be found in the chromosomal DNA in bacteria. A chromosome is much larger than the plasmids in bacterial cells; it is a molecule that determines the cells’ function and division.
A bacterium with genetic immunity to antibiotics can transfer its genetic information through plasmids to another bacterium. Resistance genes are sometimes transferred through viruses. In this case, a virus transfers the resistance gene it withdrew from one bacterium to another. And when a bacterium dies and disintegrates, another bacterium can absorb the resistance gene it releases into the immediate environment.
A non-resistant bacterium can easily add this gene to its own DNA molecules, because such resistance genes are usually in the form of tiny DNA particles called transposons that can easily be added to other DNA molecules.
In such ways, a whole colony of resistant bacteria can be formed in a short time from one resistant bacterium. This has nothing to do with evolution: The genes that make bacteria resistant did not develop through any process of mutation. Only existing genes are distributed among bacteria.

Interesting in that it demonstrates adaptation via unnatural selection (unnatural because the experimenters are selecting), but I have some questions. We are told that the bacteria have achieved this through mutations, and that is clear enough, but what in fact are the mutations doing? For example, given that the bacteria are being kept in simplified environments, are they adapting by disabling functions that they don't need in this environment to provide more energy for replicating here, or are they adapting by developing brand new functionality? If the former, they would presumably be uncompetitive if placed back in the 'wild:' devolution rather than evolution, so to speak. Even the adaptation to digest citrate could be a costly mutation in other environments where citrate isn't common (hence they didn't start with this ability), so it could be that other functions are now not feasible because of this new one: it may not be an additional ability, but an alternative one instead - so has it been achieved by breaking something else? Obviously we don't have new species created from the old ones here, but even the adaptations may be a bit more limited than they appear at first sight. It's clearly a very important experiment that shows how far this limited adaptation can be pushed in a glucose-starved environment.

How many generations will it take to naturally get something a little more developed than E.coli?
